system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

On 10th March 2024, you were admitted to our hospital with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath. Your initial evaluation included an electrocardiogram (ECG) which revealed ST elevation in leads V5 and V6, prompting admission for suspected acute coronary syndrome.

During your stay, further diagnostic evaluation on 11th March confirmed a diagnosis of ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) involving the left main coronary artery. Laboratory tests revealed elevated levels of Troponin T, indicative of myocardial injury, with results of 30 and 29 ng/L.

In accordance with hospital protocols, medical management included administration of Morphine for pain relief (2-4 mg as needed), Oxygen therapy (2-4 L/min to maintain saturation above 90%), Nitroglycerin (0.4 mg every 5 minutes for a maximum of three doses to alleviate persistent chest pain), and a single dose of Aspirin (324 mg, chewed) to inhibit platelet aggregation.

Unfortunately, due to an inability to contact the catheterization laboratory and a non-responsive cardiology team, primary coronary intervention (PCI) could not be executed.

By night-time on 12th March, you reported a resolution of chest pain and requested discharge from the hospital. At discharge, your condition appeared stable, with no further episodes of chest pain reported.

It is imperative that you adhere to follow-up care and maintain close monitoring of your cardiovascular status. Please schedule an appointment with your primary care physician to discuss ongoing management and consider referral to a cardiology specialist. It is crucial to adhere to lifestyle modifications and prescribed medications to prevent recurrence.

We recommend addressing any queries or concerns with your healthcare provider as soon as possible.

With kind regards,

___  
Resident Physician
